rule_text_en: George is very old. Nobody knows exactly how old he is, but: It is said that he is 108 years old.

Both these sentences mean: ‘People say that he is 108 years old.’ You can use these structures with a number of other verbs, especially: alleged believed considered expected known reported thought understood Cathy loves running.

rule_text_en: Study this example situation: You saw Paul yesterday and you want to tell somebody what he said. There are two ways of doing this: You can repeat Paul’s words (direct speech): Paul said, ‘I’m feeling ill.’ Or you can use reported speech: Paul said that he was feeling ill.
rule_text_uk: Study this example situation: You saw Paul yesterday and you want to tell somebody what he said. There are two ways of doing this: You can repeat Paul’s words (direct speech): Paul said, ‘I’m feeling ill.’ Or you can use reported speech: Paul said that he was feeling ill.

rule_short_uk: Study this example situation: You saw Paul yesterday and you want to tell somebody what he said.
examples: Study this example situation: You saw Paul yesterday and you want to tell somebody what he said.
There are two ways of doing this: You can repeat Paul’s words (direct speech): Paul said, ‘I’m feeling ill.’ Or you can use reported speech: Paul said that he was feeling ill.
Compare: direct Paul said, ‘ I am feeling ill.’ reported Paul said that he was feeling ill.In writing we use these quotation marks to show direct speech.
When we use reported speech, the main verb of the sentence is usually past (Paul said that … / I told her that … etc.).

rule_text_en: We do not always change the verb in reported speech. If the situation is still the same, it is not necessary to change the verb to the past.
rule_text_uk: We do not always change the verb in reported speech. If the situation is still the same, it is not necessary to change the verb to the past.
rule_short_en: We do not always change the verb in reported speech.
rule_short_uk: We do not always change the verb in reported speech.
examples: We do not always change the verb in reported speech.
If the situation is still the same, it is not necessary to change the verb to the past.
For example: direct Paul said, ‘My new job is boring.’ reported Paul said that his new job is boring.
(The situation is still the same.

rule_text_en: With a singular noun we use -’s : my sister’s room (= her room – one sister) Mr Carter’s house (= his house) With a plural noun (sisters, friends etc.) we put an apostrophe (’) after s: my sisters’ room (= their room – two or more sisters) the Carters’ house (= their house – Mr and Mrs Carter) If a plural noun does not end in -s (for example men/ women/ children/ people) we use -’s : the men’s changing room a children’s book (= a book for children) You can use -’s after more than one noun: Jack and Karen’s children Mr and Mrs Carter’s houseB For things, ideas etc., we normally use of : the temperature of the water ( not the water’s temperature) the name of the book the owner of the restaurant We say the beginning/ end/ middle of … / the top/ bottom of … / the front/ back/ side of … : the beginning of the month (not the month’s beginning) the top of the hill the back of the carC You can usually use -’s or of … for an organisation (= a group of people). So you can say: the government’s decision or the decision of the government the company’s success or the success of the company We also use -’s for places.

(not ask to me) look / stare / glance AT …, have a look / take a look AT … Why are you looking at me like that?apologise TO somebody (for …) They apologised to me for their mistake.

rule_text_en: talk / read / know ABOUT … We talked about a lot of things at the meeting. do something/nothing ABOUT something = do something/nothing to improve a situation If you’re worried about the problem, you should do something about it.
rule_text_uk: talk / read / know ABOUT … We talked about a lot of things at the meeting. do something/nothing ABOUT something = do something/nothing to improve a situation If you’re worried about the problem, you should do something about it.
rule_short_en: talk / read / know ABOUT … We talked about a lot of things at the meeting.
rule_short_uk: talk / read / know ABOUT … We talked about a lot of things at the meeting.
examples: talk / read / know ABOUT … We talked about a lot of things at the meeting.
do something/nothing ABOUT something = do something/nothing to improve a situation If you’re worried about the problem, you should do something about it.
apply ( TO a company etc.) FOR a job etc.
I think you could do this job.

rule_text_en: hear ABOUT … = be told about something Did you hear about the fire at the hotel? Some times the difference is very small and you can use of or about: When I’m alone, I often think of you.
rule_text_uk: hear ABOUT … = be told about something Did you hear about the fire at the hotel? Some times the difference is very small and you can use of or about: When I’m alone, I often think of you.
rule_short_en: hear ABOUT … = be told about something Did you hear about the fire at the hotel?
rule_short_uk: hear ABOUT … = be told about something Did you hear about the fire at the hotel?
examples: hear ABOUT … = be told about something Did you hear about the fire at the hotel?
Some times the difference is very small and you can use of or about: When I’m alone, I often think of you.
or … think about you.
You can say think of or think about doing something (for possible future actions): My sister is thinking of going to Canada.

rule_text_en: accuse / suspect somebody OF … Tina accused me of being selfish. Some students were suspected of cheating in the exam.
rule_text_uk: accuse / suspect somebody OF … Tina accused me of being selfish. Some students were suspected of cheating in the exam.
rule_short_en: accuse / suspect somebody OF … Tina accused me of being selfish.
rule_short_uk: accuse / suspect somebody OF … Tina accused me of being selfish.
examples: accuse / suspect somebody OF … Tina accused me of being selfish.
Some students were suspected of cheating in the exam.
congratulate / compliment somebody ON … I congratulated her on doing so well in her exams.
The meal was really good.

rule_text_en: believe IN … = believe that something exists, believe that it’s good to do something Do you believe in God? (= do you believe that God exists?) I believe in saying what I think.
rule_text_uk: believe IN … = believe that something exists, believe that it’s good to do something Do you believe in God? (= do you believe that God exists?) I believe in saying what I think.
rule_short_en: believe IN … = believe that something exists, believe that it’s good to do something Do you believe in God?
rule_short_uk: believe IN … = believe that something exists, believe that it’s good to do something Do you believe in God?
examples: believe IN … = believe that something exists, believe that it’s good to do something Do you believe in God?
(= do you believe that God exists?) I believe in saying what I think.
(= I believe it is right to say what I think) but ‘believe something’ (= believe that it is true), ‘believe somebody’ (= believe what they say): The story can’t be true.
I don’t believe it.

rule_text_en: Often the second word (on/ off/out etc.) gives a special meaning to the verb. For example: break down find out take off give up get on get bySorry I’m late.
rule_text_uk: Often the second word (on/ off/out etc.) gives a special meaning to the verb. For example: break down find out take off give up get on get bySorry I’m late.
rule_short_en: Often the second word (on/ off/out etc.) gives a special meaning to the verb.
rule_short_uk: Often the second word (on/ off/out etc.) gives a special meaning to the verb.
examples: Often the second word (on/ off/out etc.) gives a special meaning to the verb.
For example: break down find out take off give up get on get bySorry I’m late.
The car broke down.
(= the engine stopped working) I never found out who sent me the flowers.

rule_text_en: in = into a room, a building, a car etc. How did the thieves get in ?
rule_text_uk: in = into a room, a building, a car etc. How did the thieves get in ?
rule_short_en: in = into a room, a building, a car etc.
rule_short_uk: in = into a room, a building, a car etc.
examples: in = into a room, a building, a car etc.
How did the thieves get in ?
Here’s a key, so you can let yourself in.
Lisa walked up to the edge of the pool and dived in.

rule_text_en: out = not burning, not shining go out put out a fire / a cigarette / a light turn out a light blow out a candleSuddenly all the lights in the building went out. I put the fire out with a fire extinguisher.
rule_text_uk: out = not burning, not shining go out put out a fire / a cigarette / a light turn out a light blow out a candleSuddenly all the lights in the building went out. I put the fire out with a fire extinguisher.
rule_short_en: out = not burning, not shining go out put out a fire / a cigarette / a light turn out a light blow out a candleSuddenly all the lights in the building went out.
rule_short_uk: out = not burning, not shining go out put out a fire / a cigarette / a light turn out a light blow out a candleSuddenly all the lights in the building went out.
examples: out = not burning, not shining go out put out a fire / a cigarette / a light turn out a light blow out a candleSuddenly all the lights in the building went out.
I put the fire out with a fire extinguisher.
I turned the lights out before leaving.
We don’t need the candle.

rule_text_en: We say: the light is on / put the light on / leave the light on etc. turn the light on/ off or switch the light on/ off Shall I leave the lights on or turn them off?
rule_text_uk: We say: the light is on / put the light on / leave the light on etc. turn the light on/ off or switch the light on/ off Shall I leave the lights on or turn them off?
rule_short_en: We say: the light is on / put the light on / leave the light on etc.
rule_short_uk: We say: the light is on / put the light on / leave the light on etc.
examples: We say: the light is on / put the light on / leave the light on etc.
turn the light on/ off or switch the light on/ off Shall I leave the lights on or turn them off?
‘Is the heating on?’ ‘No, I switched it off.’ also put (music, a song) on, put the kettle on: Let’s put some music on.
What would you like to hear?

rule_text_en: go on = continue The party went on until 4 o’clock in the morning. keep on doing (or keep doing) something = do it continuously or repeatedly He keeps on criticising me.
rule_text_uk: go on = continue The party went on until 4 o’clock in the morning. keep on doing (or keep doing) something = do it continuously or repeatedly He keeps on criticising me.
rule_short_en: go on = continue The party went on until 4 o’clock in the morning.
rule_short_uk: go on = continue The party went on until 4 o’clock in the morning.
examples: go on = continue The party went on until 4 o’clock in the morning.
keep on doing (or keep doing) something = do it continuously or repeatedly He keeps on criticising me.
It’s not fair!
(or He keeps criticising me.) drive on / walk on / play on = continue driving/walking/playing etc.

rule_text_en: put something up (on a wall etc.) I put a picture up on the wall. pick something up There was a letter on the floor.

stand up Alan stood up and walked out.

rule_text_en: go up, come up, walk up ( to …) = approach A man came up to me in the street and asked me for money. set up an organisation, a company, a business, a system, a website etc.
rule_text_uk: go up, come up, walk up ( to …) = approach A man came up to me in the street and asked me for money. set up an organisation, a company, a business, a system, a website etc.

set up an organisation, a company, a business, a system, a website etc.
= start it The government has set up a committee to investigate the problem.
grow up = become an adult Amy was born in Hong Kong but grew up in Australia.

rule_text_en: bring up a topic etc. = introduce it in a conversation I don’t want to hear any more about this.

= introduce it in a conversation I don’t want to hear any more about this.

make something up = invent something that is not true What Kevin told you about himself wasn’t true.

rule_text_en: Compare away and back: away = away from home We’re going away on holiday today. away = away from a place, a person etc.
rule_text_uk: Compare away and back: away = away from home We’re going away on holiday today. away = away from a place, a person etc.
rule_short_en: Compare away and back: away = away from home We’re going away on holiday today.
rule_short_uk: Compare away and back: away = away from home We’re going away on holiday today.
examples: Compare away and back: away = away from home We’re going away on holiday today.
away = away from a place, a person etc.
Sarah got into her car, started the engine and drove away.
I tried to take a picture of the bird, but it flew away.
